title: Future Returns: Real Estate Remains a Good Bet in Some Hong Kong Sectors
text:
Text size

The Hong Kong protests that began in late March have hurt market sectors such as retail and tourism—but so far, real estate appears to be more resilient.

In fact, some of the most sought-after areas for luxury real estate in the city saw a couple of transactions in September. Knight Frank reported a house on Mount Nicholson, at The Peak, sold for HK$538.9 million (US$68.8 million), or HK$85,188 per square foot, and another on Tai Tam Road sold for a district record of HK$99,335 per square foot.

The prices show the fundamentals are still in place, says David Ji, director and head of research and consultancy for Knight Frank in Greater China.

“Hong Kong’s real estate market is not easily replaced, because other cities can’t quite match the gap between supply and demand, even with ongoing protests,” Ji says. Although the unrest has caused a nominal drop in prices, people who have been looking at the market for a long time may perceive the softness as a signal to buy, he says.

Overall, Hong Kong’s real estate market is stable and may actually rise a small amount for 2019, Ji adds. That’s because residential real estate prices rose in the first half by an average of 8% to 9%, which should offset an estimated home price decline of 5% to 6% by the end of the year.

Allan Lee, managing director of Hong Kong-based real estate investment fund Pamfleet, echoed the sentiment.

“It’s business as usual,” Lee says. “ It’ll take time to wind down, but it’s not as bad as people read and see.”

In the meantime, he has the following advice for investors.

Consider Investing in Retail or Office Properties

The residential sector gets the most attention in the city because a lack of supply has pushed prices higher, but there are opportunities elsewhere.

The market for retail properties, for ins tance, isn’t all doom-and-gloom, despite government data showing a 23% year-over-year drop in retail sales in August. Although retail rents have been severely impacted (Prada, for example, is closing its prime location in Causeway Bay when its lease expires next year), Colliers reported that three new shopping malls have opened recently, injecting new life into the market, and that Hong Kong should remain a top shopping destination despite near-term market turbulences.

Retail activity is down from a high point, Lee says, “But it went a bit crazy in the past. If you compare it to the rest of the world, it isn’t down. It’s suffering, but retail goes through cycles.”

Lee, however, suggests exercising more caution with smaller retail transactions, where competition is higher against cash-rich local investors who can quickly execute transactions.

The strongest sector today is office real estate, particularly in the city’s financial center, as Hong Kong’s central business district (CBD) is still one of the most expensive places in the world to do business due to a shortfall of Grade A office space. According to a Knight Frank report on the office market in 2020, the government has unveiled plans to increase long-term supply with a second CBD, but the specific timeline is still unclear, and the supply-demand imbalance continues.

“No matter what happens between Hong Kong and China, there will always be that demand” for office buildings. “Hong Kong is a financial market. It’s a service provider economy, not a country that produces or makes anything. The CBD is small, and it’s really the only place in China with a free-flow of capital.”

Search for Value-Add Opportunities

Because the most active players in Hong Kong’s real-estate market tend to be local investors and institutions, the months-long protests have put a stop to most activity in the city. But that doesn’t mean prices have changed. “We’re not seeing many price adjustments. Nobody is willing to lower prices because of what’s happening,” Lee says.

So the best bets are investments that add value to older properties. “Hong Kong’s real estate market is mature,” he says. “There are a lot of old buildings and it’s very densely populated, so if you can find something you can renovate and upgrade, it may be a good value.”

Don’t Speculate

“Hong Kong is not really a core market like London or Tokyo—it’s very volatile and highly liquid,” Lee says. That’s because real estate investors in the city always have made most of their profit from capital appreciation.

“Investors tend to want quick ins and quick outs,” Lee says. “That’s been driving Hong Kong’s recent real estate value[s], rather than long-term growth.” With the protests, the situation is changing on a daily basis, making it an especially dangerous time to speculate—and a likely reason why many local investors have adopted a wait-and-see approach.

Ultimately, there may be some changes to the norm going forward, but Lee says China is not putting too heavy a hand on Hong Kong.

“If China’s going to be here for [the] next 10 to 20 years, so is Hong Kong,” he says. “It’s merely a question of how long the protests will last, because Hong Kong is part of China.”
description: Home prices remain high, but investors can find opportunities in office and retail properties
